(originally Tesla Motors ) begins in 2003, with two American entrepreneurs: Marc Tarpenning and Martin Eberhard . Eberhards newly discovered passion for sports cars led them to invest in a boutique-level EV company named AC Propulsion, and the two coopted PayPal founder Elon Musk into the business in 2001. ( December 2023 ) ( Learn how and when to remove this message ) Tesla, Inc. is an electric vehicle manufacturer and clean energy company founded in San Carlos, California in 2003 by American entrepreneurs Martin Eberhard and Marc Tarpenning . The company is named after Serbian-American inventor Nikola Tesla . Tesla is the world\'s leading electric vehicle manufacturer by market cap. [ 1 ] As of 2023, Tesla\'s global vehicle sales were 1.77 million units annually, the 14th-highest total among auto manufacturers worldwide. [ 2 ] Contents 1 The beginnings Roadster and private funding 2 2009 Department of Energy loan 3 Lotus supply of Roadster parts 4 IPO and Model S 5 Used vehicles 6 Acquisitions 6.1 SolarCity 7 Model 3 rollout 8 2018 consideration of taking Tesla private 9 Financials 10 Timeline of production and sales 11 References The beginnings Roadster and private funding edit Tesla was incorporated (as Tesla Motors) on July 1, 2003, by Martin Eberhard and Marc Tarpenning in San Carlos, California. [ 3 ] [ 4 ] [ 5 ] The founders were influenced to start the company after General Motors recalled all its EV1 electric cars in 2003 and then destroyed them, [ 6 ] and seeing the higher fuel efficiency of battery-electric cars as an opportunity to break the usual correlation between high performance and low fuel economy in automobiles . [ 7 ] The AC Propulsion tzero also inspired the company\'s first vehicle, the Roadster . [ 8 ] [ 9 ] Eberhard said he wanted to build "a car manufacturer that is also a technology company", with its core technologies as "the battery, the computer software, and the proprietary motor". [ 10 ] Ian Wright was the third employee, joining a few months later. [ 3 ] The three went looking for venture capital (VC) funding in January 2004 [ 3 ] and connected with Elon Musk , who contributed US$6.5 million of the initial ( Series A ) US$7.5 million [ 11 ] round of investment in February 2004 and became chairman of the board of directors. [ 3 ] Musk then appointed Eberhard as the CEO. [ 12 ] J.B. Straubel joined in May 2004 [ 3 ] as the fifth employee. [ 13 ] A lawsuit settlement agreed to by Eberhard and Tesla in September 2009 allows all five (Eberhard, Tarpenning, Wright, Musk and Straubel) to call themselves co-founders. [ 14 ] Musk took an active role within the company and oversaw Roadster product design, but was not deeply involved in day-to-day business operations. [ 15 ] Musk insisted from the beginning on a carbon-fiber-reinforced polymer body and contributed to the car style. [ 16 ] Tesla Motors received the Global Green 2006 product design award for the design of the Tesla Roadster, presented by Mikhail Gorbachev . [ 17 ] Elon Musk, Martin Eberhard, Barney Hatt, Tesla Motors also received the 2007 Index Design award for their design of the Tesla Roadster. Tesla, originally Tesla Motors, started out in 2003 when a group of engineers, who had a passion for electric cars, wanted to show people that they didn't need to compromise when considering buying one. Tesla, Inc., formerly (200317) Tesla Motors, American manufacturer of electric automobiles, solar panels, and batteries for cars and home power storage. 2006 Musk co-led the third,US$40 million round in May 2006 along with Technology Partners. Prototypes of Tesla's first car, the Roadster, were officially revealed to the public on July 19, 2006, in Santa Monica, California, at a 350-person invitation-only event held in Barker Hangar at Santa Monica Airport. 2007 A fourth round worth $45 million in May 2007 brought the total private financing investment to over $105 million. Customers began paying deposits for the first 100 Tesla Roadsters anticipated for release in 2007; George Clooney paid $100,000 to secure one of the first Roadsters in production. Magazine names Elon Musk Entrepreneur of the Year for 2007. The loan program was created in 2007 during the George W. Bush administration. 2008 Co-founder Marc Tarpenning, who served as the Vice President of Electrical Engineering of the company, also left the company in January 2008. The fifth round in February 2008 added another US$40 million. By November 2008, the company's financial situation had worsened and Tesla was on the brink of bankruptcy. In late 2007 Eberhard resigned as CEO and president of technology and joined the advisory board of the company. It was announced in 2008 that he had left the company, though he remained a shareholder. 2009 By January 2009, Tesla had raised $187 million and delivered 147 cars. Tesla was also forced to issue a safety recall in 2009 for 345 Roadsters that were produced prior to April 22, 2009. In June 2009, Eberhard filed a lawsuit against Musk for allegedly forcing him out. In July 2009, Daimler announced that Abu Dhabis Aabar Investments bought 40% of Daimlers interest in Tesla. The company announced in early August 2009 that it had achieved overall corporate profitability for the month of July 2009. 2010 On January 29, 2010, Tesla Motors filed Form S-1 with the United States Securities and Exchange Commission, as a preliminary prospectus indicating its intention to file an initial public offering (IPO) underwritten by Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, J. P. Morgan, and Deutsche Bank Securities. Since its IPO in 2010, Elon Musk's electric-car company has contented with high highs and low lows. Tesla closed out its first day of trading in 2010 with a market cap of $2.22 billion. ( December 2023 ) ( Learn how and when to remove this message ) Tesla, Inc. is an electric vehicle manufacturer and clean energy company founded in San Carlos, California in 2003 by American entrepreneurs Martin Eberhard and Marc Tarpenning . [ 3 ] Musk then appointed Eberhard as the CEO. [ 12 ] J.B. Straubel joined in May 2004 [ 3 ] as the fifth employee. Tesla, Inc., formerly (200317) Tesla Motors, American manufacturer of electric automobiles, solar panels, and batteries for cars and home power storage. 2006 Musk co-led the third,US$40 million round in May 2006 along with Technology Partners. Prototypes of Tesla's first car, the Roadster, were officially revealed to the public on July 19, 2006, in Santa Monica, California, at a 350-person invitation-only event held in Barker Hangar at Santa Monica Airport. 2007 A fourth round worth $45 million in May 2007 brought the total private financing investment to over $105 million. Who Are Tesla's Competitors in the Current Market? 5 min to read 09 July 2025 5 min to read Who are Tesla's competitors in 2025? As the electric vehicle market rapidly evolves, understanding the key players challenging Tesla is essential for investors and automotive enthusiasts. This article provides a detailed comparison of Tesla and its major rivals, such as BYD, Rivian, Volkswagen, and General Motors, focusing on their strategies, market positions, and innovations, offering insights into the dynamic landscape of the EV industry. The Expanding Landscape of the Electric Vehicle Market Over the last decade, the electric vehicle (EV) industry has experienced remarkable growth, with Tesla often leading the charge in terms of innovation and market dominance. As we look at 2025, the competitive field is more crowded than ever, prompting a thorough exploration of Teslas main adversaries. This isnt just about naming rivals; its about dissecting the strategic changes and technological advancements each contender brings to the industry. Teslas Major Competitors in Detail BYD (Build Your Dreams) BYD, rooted in China, has established a significant presence in the EV sector by prioritizing affordability and leveraging its robust domestic market. Holding more than 20% of the market share in China and expanding internationally, BYD stands as a formidable adversary for Tesla. Their strategy of crafting budget-friendly vehicles that dont skimp on quality makes them attractive to a wide consumer base. Rivian Rivian has carved its niche as a direct competitor to Tesla, particularly in the electric truck and SUV arenas. With substantial backing from giants like Amazon and Ford, Rivians R1T and R1S models have been praised for their performance and unique features. Their focus on adventure-oriented vehicles appeals to consumers seeking both sustainability and rugged utility. Volkswagen (VW) Volkswagens ambitious $50 billion investment in EV development highlights its commitment to electrification, aiming for a comprehensive model lineup by 2025. The ID. series, featuring models like the ID.4 and the ID.Buzz, has captivated audiences in Europe and the U.S. With a vast distribution network and a storied brand legacy, Volkswagen is well-positioned to challenge Teslas market stronghold. General Motors (GM) General Motors has placed electrification at the heart of its strategy, pledging to unveil 30 electric models by 2025. The Chevrolet Bolt and the upcoming electric Silverado showcase GMs shift from traditional engines to electric powertrains. With extensive manufacturing expertise and global outreach, GM is poised to compete with Tesla in the mass market segment.
